Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Human-Building Interaction Framework for Responsive and Adaptive Built Environments

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant is to advance knowledge about the impact of human-building interactions on energy use, and to explore intelligent, collaborative, and personalized approaches that connect built environments with their users to increase energy efficiency and awareness. Taxonomies of types, features, and patterns of human-building interactions will be developed, based on high-resolution building and human related data. The impact of human-building interactions on energy use and comfort will be quantitatively described using a simulation environment that incorporates multiple simulations and modeling technologies. The research will build on the concept of heterogeneous teamwork between building members and their users, through the use of computer agents that represent and interact with these building systems and their users. A model, capable of learning user preferences for automation, will be employed. A diverse set of communication strategies and styles will be evaluated through human subject experiments that address actions influencing energy and comfort, and increase the trust between humans and the built environment.

If successful, the research will advance the understanding about the impact of human-building interactions on energy, and transform built environments into attentive and self-learning entities that adapt to user preferences of energy conservation. User-related information will be incorporated into building operations thus allowing for proactive accommodation of user needs. Knowledge of human-building interactions will support engineering design and management activities, and foster the evolution of built environments as eco-systems. To increase public engagement, energy related workshops will be organized bringing together parents, teachers and K-12 students to build hands on engineering projects. High school female students will develop computer applications related to energy conservation, attracting them to engineering and technology fields. The work will engage underrepresented students and develop new materials, modules, courses, test beds for research and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant was to advance our knowledge about the impact of human-building interactions on energy use and to explore intelligent, collaborative, and personalized approaches that connect built environments with their users to increase energy efficiency and awareness. The team developed several algorithms for modeling occupancy patterns and occupant thermal comfort preferences, using high-resolution building and human data. The team also developed several control algorithms for implementing personalized profiles into building management systems and quantified the comfort and energy consequences of using preferences in commercial buildings through simulation studies as well as field implementations. In addition, the team investigated the patterns and frequencies of human-building interactions under multimodal discomfort conditions, and explored the underlying reasons for these interactions, with a specific focus on heating, cooling and lighting devices. A model, capable of learning user preferences for automation, was developed and employed. The team also developed algorithms for activity detection and recognition to explore the dependency of preferences for automation on contextual and temporal factors. In an effort to understand, what kinds of communication strategies and styles are most effective for human-building communication, the team studied effectiveness of social messages on energy consumption behavior in buildings through human subject experiments. Through these studies, user-related information has been incorporated into building operations thus allowing for proactive accommodation of user needs. Knowledge of human-building interactions supports engineering design and management activities and fosters the evolution of built environments as user-centered ecosystems.


This CAREER project advances our understanding about the impact of human-building interactions on energy consumption and the influence of user-centered mathematical models on trust in automation. Through the findings of this research, we can transform our built environments into attentive and self-learning entities that adapt to user preferences while conserving energy. The work supported the research of several PhD students. Six minority undergraduate students were included in research activities through a 10-week summer program over three summers. In addition, the team hosted four middle and high school teachers from LAUSD (Los Angeles Unified School District) for 5-weeks over two summers and through this collaboration, research findings were integrated into the 6-8th grade curricula. In addition, three undergraduate students took part in research through the REU supplement. In collaboration with Iridescent Learning, the research team designed three open ended engineering challenges that focus on energy conservation in buildings. These challenges are published at the curiositymachine.org website, exposing K-6 students to engineering and technology challenges and encouraging them to consider careers in these areas. The team also developed new materials and modules for undergraduate and graduate civil engineering courses. The findings of this work were disseminated through and contribute to multiple peer-reviewed publications, conference talks and invited presentations.
